snippet: The stylish clientele is not just avoiding Times Square. Rooms in Long Island City, Williamsburg, downtown Brooklyn and other areas are better priced, and in neighborhoods with genuine attractions.
abstract: New York City hotel market is booming, with at least 15 stylish hotels opened in the five boroughs in 2011, roughly half of them outside Manhattan; Brooklyn and Queens are at the forefront of the growing industry as guests take advantage of cheaper prices, close proximity to the city and genuine attractions and interest in those areas.

headline.main: Stylish Hotels Sprouting in Brooklyn and Queens
headline.print_headline: Stylish Hotels Sprouting in Brooklyn and Queens

snippet: Members of Greenpeace, the environmental advocacy group, released balloons in the Apple store on Fifth Avenue to call attention to the company's use of coal power at its facilities.
abstract: Members of Greenpeace, the environmental advocacy group, released balloons in the Apple store on Fifth Avenue to call attention to the company's use of coal power at its facilities.

headline.main: Greenpeace Protests Apple's Energy Practices By Releasing Balloons

snippet: The iPad has been nothing less than a phenomenon, though many Wall Street analysts seem to miss that point. In just two years Apple has sold 67 million iPads. It took Apple 24 years to sell as many Macs, five years to sell as many iPods and over t...
abstract: The iPad has been nothing less than a phenomenon, though many Wall Street analysts seem to miss that point. In just two years Apple has sold 67 million iPads. It took Apple 24 years to sell as many Macs, five years to sell as many iPods and over three years to sell as many iPhones.

headline.main: Tim Cook Spells Out the Rapid Growth of Apple's iPad

snippet: Is the Republican ideal of family just a rhetorical device, or is it still a worthy goal for public policy?
abstract: Is the Republican ideal of family just a rhetorical device, or is it still a worthy goal for public policy?

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday's selection includes an explanation of what the recent Tupac Shakur 'hologram' really was, a criticism of Yelp with suggested improv...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday's selection includes an explanation of what the recent Tupac Shakur 'hologram' really was, a criticism of Yelp with suggested improvements and Amazon's agreement with Nevada to collect sales tax.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Arrested in Russia and Nokia's Problems

snippet: Ariane Friedrich, an Olympic high-jump hopeful, published the personal details of a fan who sent her a sexually explicit message, prompting a stir in a country where the right to privacy is sacrosanct.

headline.main: Facebook Fight in Germany Leads to Battle Over Privacy
headline.print_headline: A Battle Over Rights Erupts in Germany

snippet: Sales in China helped lift overall iPhone sales by 88 percent over the same quarter a year ago, dispelling fears that sales would lag in nations with lower annual incomes.
abstract: Apple says sales in China helped the company sell 35.1 million iPhones in the latest quarter, an 88 percent increase from the period a year ago; 11.8 million iPads were also sold, more than double the number in the same quarter last year; company reports net income of $11.62 billion, or $12.30 a share, compared with $5.99 billion, or $6.40 a share, in the period a year earlier; Apple’s revenue was $39.19 billion, up from $24.67 billion a year ago.

headline.main: Apple Profit Rises on Higher iPhone and iPad Sales
headline.print_headline: After iPhone Sales Bonanza in China, Apple’s Profit Nearly Doubles

snippet: At least once a month, a New Yorker arrives at home to find a white paper bag hanging on the doorknob.
abstract: Laura M Holson describes her experiences sharing homemade foods with neighbors in her Upper West Side apartment building.

snippet: Joaquín Almunia, the European competition commissioner, has been open to a settlement with Google on claims it abused its dominance.
abstract: Google remains hopeful that it can reach a deal that would let the company avoid formal antitrust charges in Europe, which could mean years of expensive litigation and encourage comparable action in other parts of the world; European Union's competition commissioner, Joaquin Almunia, has suggested he is open to a settlement with Google on claims that it abused its dominance.

headline.main: Change of Tone Could Help Google in European Antitrust Case
headline.print_headline: Changes in Europe Could Help Google In Antitrust Case

snippet: There's no sign that Apple's iPhone is losing momentum. The popular smartphone remains a strong seller for both AT&T and Verizon, the nation's two big carriers, even at a time when the number of new contract customers is slowing down to a crawl.
abstract: There's no sign that Apple's iPhone is losing momentum. The popular smartphone remains a strong seller for both AT&T and Verizon, the nation's two big carriers, even at a time when the number of new contract customers is slowing down to a crawl.

headline.main: The iPhone Is Still a Strong Seller for AT&T and Verizon
